item.title: What we're looking for in Australia's Space Agency: views from NSW and SA
item.description: It’s been a long time coming, but Australia is finally going to have a Space Agency. This will enable Australian space industries to benefit from agency-to-agency agreements and collaborations, and facilitate our participation in the growing global space market.

item.title: Victoria's sperm donor laws yield some surprises, but mostly happy ones
item.description: Many Victorians are now discovering for the first time that they have offspring from sperm donations made in Victorian clinics in the 1970s and 1980s.

item.title: Trust Me, I'm An Expert: Brain-zapping, the curious case of the n-rays and other stories of evidence
item.description: You’ve had an x-ray before but have you had an n-ray? Of course not, because they’re not real.

item.title: Is psychiatry ready for medical MDMA?
item.description: Within five years, science will likely have answered a controversial question: can methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) treat psychiatric disorders?

item.title: Howling Girls: a bold experiment exploring female voices constricted by trauma
item.description: In broad terms, “opera” denotes some combination of music, drama and spectacle in which some, if not all of the words are sung. Damien Ricketson’s new theatre work, The Howling Girls, which premiered on Wednesday, 28 March at Carriageworks in Sydney, has no recognizable words and certainly stretches generic boundaries.

item.title: Grattan on Friday: Tim Storer – the $35 billion dollar man
item.description: Put yourself in the shoes of Tim Storer. The accidental senator from South Australia has one hell of a decision to make shortly after the May budget, when the government plans to bring back its legislation to give tax cuts to big business.

item.title: Essays On Air: Monsters in my closet – how a geographer began mining myths
item.description: So you think the Loch Ness Monster never existed? Think again.

item.title: Essays On Air: Monsters in my closet – how a geographer began mining myths
item.description: So you think the Loch Ness Monster never existed? Think again.

item.title: Can the cricketers banned for ball tampering ever regain their hero status? It's happened before
item.description: Overnight, Cricket Australia handed out its promised “significant sanctions” for a ball-tampering incident that has engulfed the sport in scandal. Steve Smith and David Warner, the team’s captain and vice-captain, have been banned for 12 months. Cameron Bancroft, who carried out the failed plot, received a nine-month ban.

item.title: Australia's digital divide is not going away
item.description: Despite large investments in the National Broadband Network, the “digital divide” in Australia remains largely unchanged, according to a new report from the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
